text: rukmi by and her family have been
struggling to get food on the table
three years ago her husband took his own
life he had borrowed $500 to build his
house but he was unable to make enough
money from the family farm to repay the
debt
rukmi bhai says money was a constant
worry for him she's now hoping a
government plan to forgive loans for
farmers will help ease the burden for
her family my son and I work on somebody
else's farm together we own $3.00 per
day but that is not sufficient due to
the high debt we have to repay if the
government cancels the loan repayment
then it will give us some respite almost
all the farmers in this village are
among the 7.7 million people across
Maharashtra who applied for their loan
repayments to be cancelled over the last
ten years consecutive droughts and
unseasonal rain has damaged crops across
the state forcing farmers to borrow more
money in order to continue with farming
and support their families farming
income has been declining across most of
India prompting farmers across the
country to take the streets to highlight
their plight Maharashtra is one of five
states that have announced programs that
would erase these debts but farmers say
they still don't know if their loans
have been cancelled and even then they
say the policy won't stop the crisis
known repayment cancellations won't
solve our problems the main issue is
that we don't get proper remuneration
for the crops we grow if the government
raises the prices of our crops then our
financial condition will surely improve
we don't have proper irrigation
facilities for our farms secondly we
need 24 hours of electricity if these
things are provided then we wouldn't
need any kind of financial help
Maharashtra is expected to spend more
than five million dollars to cancel all
loan repayments
but experts say that the policy is bad
economics which will only drain state
finances and not address the root of the
problem
Samir Hashmi BBC News rural Maharashtra
